candidates.title: New releases for all HAL packages
Add support for 26Mhz xtal in ESP32-HAL
candidates.body:
Referencing Issue #329, these changes add support for 26Mhz crystals to be used with the ESP32.

These changes were made in reference to the changes in PR #301 where support was added for 26Mhz crystals for the ESP32c2 chip. As such the changes here were almost identical, I have tried to keep the same convention for the features to select between crystal varieties as in #301.

I have tested these changes with a Sparkfun ESP32 Thing (the same board as referenced in #329) using the example projects in [esp32-hal](https://github.com/esp-rs/esp-hal/tree/main/esp32-hal/examples) and while I am not able to test the projects with external devices such as those using i2c (as I do not have any sensors/devices to connect) all examples using the standalone esp32 seem to be working correctly. I also unfortunately do not own a 40Mhz esp32 to test these changes on (to ensure it still works), though the examples are being built without error.

Sorry if this PR doesn't follow convention, as this is my first. I'd love any feedback on things I can improve for next time!

candidates.title: Remove unnecessary `rt` crate dependencies
candidates.body:
Fixes #382 

- remove dependencies to `rt` crates and `riscv` / `xtensa-lx` from the chip specific HALs, re-export from esp-hal-common
- re-export `riscv` / `xtensa-lx` in the chip specific HALs
- `entry` is re-exported and added to the prelude
- atomic emulation is always included by the HAL for ESP32-S2 (like it's already the case for ESP32-C2 / ESP32-C3)

This PR looks huge but most of the changes are in the examples.

Nice side-effect: fixes #197 

This has some potential for bikeshedding about some names (e.g. `trapframe::TrapFrame`) - I tried to choose the names carefully but don't have strong opinions about them

_BEFORE_ merging this
- [x] publish a new `xtensa-lx-rt` version, probably also `xtensa-lx`
- [x] publish the PACs (with removed `rt` dependencies)
- [x] optionally wait for a new published `esp-backtrace`

This also bumps the versions of all contained crates

candidates.title: Async SPI
candidates.body:
This PR implements a `Future` based abstraction around the current DMA implementations and uses said abstraction to implement the Async SPI traits from e-h on `SpiDma`.

FYI the diff looks kinda weird because of the fmt commit, perhaps compare the commits _before_ that fmt commit for easier viewing.

## Breaking changes

`dma::private`, `gdma::private`, and `pdma::private` no longer exist. All the DMA types/traits are now public. The ideal solution would be to erase these types see #381.

## Future work

- The error handling for the DMA needs some work at the moment DMA errors are unchecked.
- We could implement the e-h-a SPI traits on the normal `Spi` struct using the peripheral FIFO + interrupts, but this is less efficient and unnecessary for this initial implementation.

candidates.title: Use the new `esp-riscv-rt` package for RISC-V HALs
candidates.body: I hope I got this all right 😁 I've done some basic testing and things seem to be working as expected though! Also need to verify that atomic emulation is still working after my changes.

candidates.title: Update the name of the `INTERRUPT` peripheral to `INTERRUPT_CORE0`
candidates.body: I was doing some interrupt-related cleanup in the SVDs and noticed that this peripheral was not in line with the other PACs, so I've updated it. Nothing exciting, but one less `#[cfg()]` 😁

candidates.title: New releases for all HAL packages
Refactor `rtc_cntl` module and add `get_reset_reason` function
candidates.body:
I realize this is a bit of an odd PR on its own, but I am building towards some other more interesting work. This was pretty self-contained so I figured I'd just PR it now.

The `rtc_cntl` module is going to grow quite a bit, so I've pulled it into its own module directory. The `rtc` module followed it into this directory as well.

The `get_reset_reason` function is pretty simple and basically just maps a ROM function's return value to an enum, `SocResetReason`. There were a few variants which had conflicting values, so I have noted these in comments and, IMO, provided a reasonable workaround, at least for the time being.

candidates.title: Update a number of dependencies to get RISC-V HALs building again
candidates.body:
The `riscv@0.9.0` package was yanked, and this is dealing with the fallout of that.

Closes #349

candidates.title: pulse counter implementation
candidates.body:
This is complete. I implemented this following LEDC as a guide and I'm not completely happy with the resulting API.  Some possibilities:
- implement each unit as a peripheral (PCNT0, PCNT1 etc) and initialize the clock when the first unit is configured. This would eliminate the unit::Number which is confusing with channel::Number.
- don't put the channel implementation in a separate  module.
- don't make Channel an object and just have configure_channel(ch: Channel, config: ChannelConfig) as a method on the unit.

candidates.title: Peripheral ref/gpio
candidates.body:
The final update in this conversion step.

A couple of things had to change to get this working:

- I2S pin structs now have constructors
- MSRV bumped to 1.65 because pulse control traits now use GATs

I *think* I've covered everywhere we use pins but I would appreciate a triple-check on that.

candidates.title: Support ESP32-C2 with 26MHz Xtal
candidates.body:
According to [ESP-IDF](https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-idf/en/release-v5.0/esp32c2/get-started/windows-setup.html#get-started-windows-first-steps:~:text=If%20IDF%20monitor%20fails%20shortly%20after%20the%20upload%2C%20or%2C%20if%20instead%20of%20the%20messages%20above%2C%20you%20see%20random%20garbage%20similar%20to%20what%20is%20given%20below%2C%20your%20board%20is%20likely%20using%20a%2026%20MHz%20crystal.%20Most%20development%20board%20designs%20use%2040%20MHz%2C%20so%20ESP%2DIDF%20uses%20this%20frequency%20as%20a%20default%20value.) most development boards use a 40MHz xtal but 26MHz are available so it makes sense to support it.

However, since 40MHz is also the default for ESP-IDF it's also the default for esp-hal.

I tested this on both, 40MHz and 26MHz versions and checked SPI, I2C and UART with a logic analyzer - looks good.

Please note: If you are using a 26MHz chip you need to supply a custom bootloader configured for 26MHz otherwise clock config will panic.

Also this changes the _run_ alias to include the `flash` command - since `espflash 2.0` RCs are available for some time now we should do that - also apparently I'm the only one using `cargo run`

candidates.title: Fix clippy warnings, update READMEs
candidates.body: Closes #282

candidates.title: GPIO module refactoring
candidates.body:
This started as an attempt to avoid pinning the `paste` dependency but ended up it a larger refactoring of the GPIO module

The only breaking change is that the `gpio::gpio_types` is now gone and the types are directly contained in `gpio`

- reduce the number of macros, no nested macros anymore
- remaining macros don't try to be clever
- should be easier to maintain and extend (hopefully)
- might be helpful for the larger GPIO rewrite (or might not - at least it doesn't make that more difficult and might give us more time there since necessary improvements are unblocked now)
- implementing things like type-erasure should be simpler now
- removes some unused confusing things (like many unused macro parameters)
- all the pins, dac and adc are now contained in esp-hal-common which might make some things easier (like defaults for `None` pins)

It's still far from perfect - especially `into_analog` isn't much improved.  Also, the file structure is a bit odd. However, this PR is already quite big and we can still improve things in future

candidates.title: MCPWM MVP implementation
candidates.body:
## Major things missing:

- [x] Need to resolve TODOs
- [x] Documentation
- [x] Test on ESP32 Hardware
- [x] Test on ESP32-S3 Hardware
- [ ] something else?

## Request for feedback:

### Are we allowed to copy text passages from the reference manuals for documentation? What about pictures?
The MCPWM peripheral is quite complex with lots of moving parts so adding some graphics might help.

### What are people thinking about the API design? 
I chose an implementation without looking much at the existing `LEDC` code or the ESP IDF API.
There might be some disconnect here.

Things I tried to consider were (in no particular order):
* compile errors over runtime errors
* "zero-cost"-ness
* use of const-generics with the option of using [adt_const_params](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/95174) at some later point
* ability to add more features later without major architectural changes
* discoverability

I'd love to have some feedback here whether these goal were accomplished and if other considerations were missed.

### What's the pwm period of a Count-Up-Down Mode timer?
~~The [docs ](https://www.espressif.com/sites/default/files/documentation/esp32-s3_technical_reference_manual_en.pdf) mention:~~
~~> The PWM timer starts increasing from zero until the period value is reached. Then, the timer decreases back to zero. This pattern is then repeated. The PWM period is the result of (the value of the period field × 2 + 1)~~

~~Looking at the timing diagrams is seems to me that it would rather be `period field × 2`. Is that a mistake in the docs?~~

Doing some measurements confirmed that the docs indeed are wrong here the period is `period field × 2`
